ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: We had asynchronous days where we could be responsible for completing work that was assigned specifically on those days.
occasional live virtual lecture components
Asynchronous supersite assignments and sporadically assigned live virtual tests and quizzes.
Live virtual lecture
We would take tests/quizzes on Canvas with Zoom on in case we had questions that needed clarification from the professor.

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: General understanding of level 2 spanish grammar and vocabulary. More insight into the culture of Spanish speaking countries.
Spanish grammar, culture of Spain and Latin American countries
Furthered development of my Spanish language proficiency.
I strengthened my understanding of grammatical concepts, as well as awareness for different Spanish and Latin American cultures and traditions.

I learned the importance of knowing the culture of Spanish speaking countries around the globe and how certain biases are made when Americans think of Spanish Speaking Countries. I also learned what it means to give a great presentation in Spanish or English: Stick to the point, keep the topics arranged logically, be concise and show interest in what you are teaching or presenting.
I learned how to read, write, and speak Spanish more proficiently.  I also learned about the cultures of different Spanish-speaking countries through presentations given weekly by my peers.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strengths: Multiple meeting times allows for re-enforcement  of material.

Weaknesses: Lack of extra credit (or the fact that grades arent rounded) put a lot of stress on an already difficult and harshly scored class.

It is a very fast-paced class and we tend to brush over many concepts before we have an opportunity to master them. The tests are also very difficult and expectations are very high for what is supposed to be a beginner-level Spanish class. It is almost as if you have to come into the class being fluent in Spanish in order to obtain high grades on exams.

Strengths would include well structured class time that allowed for engaging participation in the course.

Weaknesses would be focused on the amount of homework and assignments we received weekly which I think indicates a lack of understanding on the professor's part of what a reasonable amount of work would be. The amount of work demanded, especially on presentations and projects, very often detracted from time that would have been more valuably spent on other courses.

I believe that this course could be improved by moving away from canvas tests and quizzes. The majority of points lost on canvas quizzes and tests was not due to incorrect spanish, but due to minor discrepancies between what the question asked and the one word answers that the program allows. The students would find the class far more fair and understanding if the grading was done by a person and not by a computer.

Strengths: 
Learning how to give presentations in Spanish.
Learning verb tenses in the future, preterite, imperfect, past perfect, subjunctive, and imperative


Weaknesses:
Hard to hear things given connection to internet: Including a live transcript or subtitle feature on zoom so everyone can read what is being said live.
Engaging and getting to know classmates: More activities learning about others and letting the Spanish they speak come from their hearts

Strengths: extremely detailed syllabus, follows the book closely, abundant access to professor through email and office hours
Weaknesses: fast paced, occasionally unclear instructions

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would have preferred to have class every day as opposed to M/W/F because speaking and listening to Spanish every day would have helped me develop my skills more.
The class was completely virtual so nothing could be changed.

Breakout-rooms were somewhat successful in engaging all participants in speaking Spanish however more time could be used in these spaces. Longer activities could be helpful in building trust in classmates and feeling relaxed talking with them.

The course was taught completely on Zoom with all resources made available online.  Professor Ramos tried her best with technological difficulties, but sometimes we would have to end class early or skip an interactive part of a lesson if the technology wasn't working.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: If you are passionate about the spanish language I would recommend this course. This is not a throw away language requirement course.
I would not recommend taking this class as your language requirement unless you have significant preparation in Spanish prior to taking this course.

This course gives a solid basis in the Spanish language and I definitely felt that I better understood the language and culture upon finishing the course. That being said, I would only recommend this course if the person in question was not proficient enough in the language to move to a higher level course.

Yes, if you want to begin to learn Spanish after continuing from high school, this is the place to be. At times you will feel uncomfortable with yourself, especially if you are not the best at present but you will come out on the other side of the class with the knowledge of Spanish and the ability to think in Spanish.

I would recommend this course to any student looking to move forward with the language requirements or looking to become proficient in Spanish.  I would not recommend this class to anyone who does not need to take it because of one of those two reasons.
